results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film captures some of the highlights of Sydney in 1962 – the harbour and bridge, memorials, gardens, building sites and streets and historic houses, as well as people working, fishing, playing bowls, sailing and catching ferries. There is a focus on traffic and cars around the inner Sydney area such as a wonderful scene of a double decker bus and taxis of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title ‘Sydney 1962’
00:00:14:00 a man is wandering around the Sydney University campus
00:01:00:00 views of Sydney whilst driving through traffic
00:01:34:00 Lennox Bridge at Parramatta.
00:01:44:00 a sign for Windsor followed by footage of historic houses
00:03:22:00 Sydney Harbour Bridge and ferry
00:06:31:00 Sydney Anzac Memorial
00:06:46:00 City Bowling Club
00:07:09:00 Sydney ‘El Alamein Memorial Fountain’
00:07:20:00 scenes at ‘Vaucluse House’
00:07:54:00 yachts sailing around the harbour
00:08:38:00 an Ansett seaplane at a pier
00:08:48:00 people fishing of a small pier
00:08:56:00 Sydney double decker bus and taxis
00:10:30:00 Rural Bank of NSW building
00:11:20:00 large excavation at a building site leaving a narrow house standing to the side
00:12:05:00 ferry ‘Kooleen’ followed by scenes shot from a boat or ferry of the harbouside

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film is mostly focused on the Snowy Mountains Scheme in New South Wales, an integrated water and hydro-electric power utility constructed between 1949 and 1974, located in Australia’s Southern Alps.

There are also some scenes of travel around Brisbane in Queensland.

Frequent title cards assist the viewer with detail, particularly regarding the workings of the hydro Scheme.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title ‘Snowy Mountain Scheme 1957’
00:00:22:00 the Snowy Mountain Authority buildings
00:00:44:00 title card ‘Guthega Dam’ followed by views of the dam
00:01:45:00 views of the accommodation buildings
00:02:00:00 title card ‘Guthega Power Station’
00:02:14:00 several views of a large cement pipeline
00:02:55:00 title card ‘Island Bend’
00:03:11:00 a four wheel drive vehicle at the site
00:03:19:00 a Pioneer Express bus waiting for passengers
00:03:22:00 sign ‘Snowy Mountain Lookout’ followed by wide vistas of the mountains
00:03:44:00 title card ‘Adaminaby Dam’
00:04:03:00 trucks working in a quarry and the clearance of trees for the workings of the Scheme
00:04:50:00 workers atop a tower construction
00:05:15:00 sign for the contractors, ‘Etudes Et Enterprises’ at the T.I. power station
00:05:31:00 title card ‘Tumut Ponds’
00:05:48:00 mouths of tunnels into the mountainsides
00:06:27:00 title card ‘Cabramurra’
00:07:41:00 title card ‘Cooma Airport’
00:07:45:00 airplane for Butler Air Transport
00:08:14:00 title card ‘Queensland 1957’
00:08:19:00 Brisbane City Hall
00:08:50:00 title card ‘Mt Coot-Tha’
00:09:14:00 title card ‘Brisbane River’, followed by views of the river
00:09:55:00 ‘Koalas at Lone Pine’ followed by a koala sitting on a dog’s back, and kangaroos
00:10:35:00 ‘Glasshouse Mountains’
00:11:00:00 ‘Long Island’ and a map of the coast of Queensland showing the location
00:11:20:00 beach scenes and an open four wheel drive modified to take passengers from small boats to the shore and on to the holiday huts
00:12:24:00 fishing scenes and wooden boxes full of fish
00:12:40:00 title card ‘Visit to South Molle’
00:13:57:00 title card ‘Visit to Happy Bay’ followed by views around the beach and bay area
00:16:08:00 title card ‘Departure of Guests’ and the holiday visitors are taken on the modified jeep to a small boat, bound for the ferry

group_works.title: Bruce Dawe
group_works.creator_credit: Linda Kruger, Robin Hughes, SBS-TV and Film Australia

results.title: Bruce Dawe
results.creator_credit: Linda Kruger, Robin Hughes, SBS-TV and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
An intimate encounter with the extraordinary “poet of suburbia”, Bruce Dawe, whose ability to evoke the drama and beauty of everyday life has set him amongst the most accessible and highly regarded of Australian poets. His highly empathic style of writing stems from a staggered history of variant occupations, contact with those from a diversity of backgrounds and failed studies as he drifted through his early years with a skill for writing but little direction. Here his motivations and writing process as they have since stood are explored. He discusses his family history and early life, his fascinations and motivations and his view of his place in the poetry world of giving a voice to ordinary Australians. Through interviews with Dawe, footage of him reading his poetry and commentary on his life and writing this is a comprehensive personal insight into Bruce Dawe’s life and influences.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Linda Kruger, Robin Hughes, SBS-TV and Film Australia

group_works.title: Graeme Bell

results.title: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Rosalie Kunoth-Monks: Aboriginal activist, actor, social worker, Parliamentary Candidate 1979-1981, President Aboriginal Legal Aid NT 1983-87, 1990-93, was born in Utopia, Central Australia, 1937 and is of German Aboriginal parentage. Kunoth-Monks discusses her education at St Mary’s Children’s Hostel, Alice Springs, and on being discovered by Charles and Elsa Chauvel as the lead in “Jedda”. She talks about working on the film, and her family’s response to it, in particular the sexual references. A greater passion was to help people, and Rosalie joined the Community of the Holy Name in Melbourne and was a nun for ten years, also gaining training during this period in childcare. Working as an Aboriginal liaison officer in Victoria after leaving the sisterhood, Kunoth-Monks also established the first Aboriginal Family Group home, in addition to marrying during this period. A return to Central Australia saw her working for the Country Liberal Party and being active in social welfare before she returned, full circle, to Utopia.

results.title: Graeme Bell
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Sharon Connolly and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Often described as the ‘father of Australian jazz’ Graeme Bell has had a sixty year love affair with music, both as a performer and a composer. Discover the story of his life, speak to the man about his passion, and hear his wonderful music.

group_works.title: Land of the long weekend

group_works.title: Sheep's back
group_works.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Susan Ardill and Film Australia

results.title: Sheep's back
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Susan Ardill and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Australia rode on the sheep’s back for over a century. Wool and the people who grew it became entwined with our national identity and the image of the sheep adorned postage stamps and coinage. The Country Party was a powerful force in Australian politics, however by the 1960’s it was Australia’s mineral deposits, particularly iron ore which began to dominate trade. As a consequence, rural Australians found themselves out of step with Australians living in our rapidly changing cities. This excellent documentary looks at the history of wool and examines what the future holds for those Australians who once rode upon the sheep’s back.

results.title: Populate or perish
results.brief_description: Explores Australia’s population debate showing how after 50 years of continuous growth, new arguments about limiting Australia’s population are emerging. This program examines the post-war era when the cry to “Populate or perish” fostered Government sponsored immigration shemes, provided the applicants were white. It traces the gradual evolution of Australia as a multicultural society, primarily concentrated on the east coast.

It traces the gradual evolution of Australia as a multicultural society, primarily concentrated on the east coast.
description_for_label: Explores Australia’s population debate showing how after 50 years of continuous growth, new arguments about limiting Australia’s population are emerging. This program examines the post-war era when the cry to “Populate or perish” fostered Government sponsored immigration shemes, provided the applicants were white. It traces the gradual evolution of Australia as a multicultural society, primarily concentrated on the east coast.
